articles.title: Seafarers were visiting remote Arctic islands over 4000 years ago
articles.summary: The first people to reach the Kitsissut Islands off the north-west coast of Greenland were Indigenous peoples, who crossed over 50 kilometres of treacherous water
articles.content:
The first people to reach the Kitsissut Islands off the north-west coast of Greenland were Indigenous peoples, who crossed over 50 kilometres of treacherous water

A site on Isbjørne Island where Palaeo-Inuit people erected a circular tent Matthew Walls, Mari Kleist, Pauline Knudsen

Humans were voyaging to remote islands off the north-west coast of Greenland 4500 years ago. This required them to cross over 50 kilometres of open water – one of the longest sea journeys made by Indigenous peoples in the Arctic.

These intrepid seafarers were the first humans to ever reach these islands, says archaeologist John Darwent at the University of California, Davis, who wasn’t involved in the study.

In 2019, Matthew Walls at the University of Calgary in Canada and his colleagues surveyed the Kitsissut Islands, also known as the Carey Islands, north-west of Greenland. The islands lie in the Pikialasorsuaq polynya, an area of open water surrounded by sea ice. Studies of marine sediments indicate that the polynya only formed about 4500 years ago.

The researchers focused on the three central islands: Isbjørne, Mellem and Nordvest. They found five sites with a total of 297 archaeological features. The biggest clusters were on Isbjørne, along beach terraces. There, the team found traces of 15 circular tents, each divided into two halves by stones, with a central hearth. These “bilobate” tents are characteristic of the Paleo-Inuit, the first peoples to reach northern Canada and Greenland.

Walls and his colleagues radiocarbon-dated a single wing bone from a seabird called a thick-billed murre, found in one of the tent rings. They estimate the bone is 4400 to 3938 years old. This indicates that people were on the Kitsissut Islands by this time, very soon after the polynya formed.

“There’s a nesting colony of thick-billed murre,” says Walls. People would have collected their eggs and hunted them for meat. He suspects they also hunted seals.

The Paleo-Inuit were already on Greenland by this time and probably voyaged west from there to Kitsissut, says Walls. “The shortest distance is about 52.7 kilometres.” However, given prevailing currents and winds, they probably set off from a more northerly point, resulting in a longer but safer journey. To the west of Kitsissut is Ellesmere Island, which today is part of Canada, but it is further away and the currents in between are challenging.

The only comparable sea journey known from Arctic prehistory is the crossing of the 82-kilometre Bering Strait, from Siberia into Alaska, which was probably first made at least 20,000 years ago. However, the Diomede Islands serve as a stopping point halfway across.

“They did have to have some sophisticated watercraft in order to cross that stretch of water,” says Darwent. Given the size of the community on Kitsissut, single-person kayaks wouldn’t have been enough. “It is whole families, and you’re not going to be able to take kids and maybe elderly across into that sort of area with kayaks,” he says. Instead, the Paleo-Inuit must have used larger craft that could carry perhaps nine or 10 people.

No boat remains were found on Kitsissut, and such remains are scarce in the Arctic. “They would have been skin-on-frame watercraft,” says Walls, like those used by later Inuit communities.

These first Paleo-Inuit settlers would have helped shape the ecosystem of Kitsissut, says Walls. By bringing nutrients in from the sea and leaving their waste on land, they fertilised the barren soils and enabled vegetation to grow on the islands. “You have rich vegetation there, at least at the start, that’s dependent in some ways on humans who are part of the cycling of nutrients between those systems.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant archaeological discovery revealing that Indigenous peoples made sophisticated long-distance sea voyages to remote Arctic islands over 4000 years ago. This finding broadens understanding of human migration, maritime technology, and ecological impact in prehistoric times, offering meaningful insight into human history with broad cultural and scientific significance.
articles.personality_title: Indigenous peoples sailed to remote Arctic islands over 4,000 years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 4,500 years ago, the Arctic region near Greenland was changing. A new area of open water, called a polynya, formed near the Kitsissut Islands, which are far off the north-west coast of Greenland. This made travel by sea possible in a place usually covered by ice.

**What happened** – In 2019, researchers led by Matthew Walls studied the Kitsissut Islands and found evidence that Indigenous Paleo-Inuit people were living there over 4,000 years ago. They discovered remains of circular tents and a bird bone dating back about 4,400 years. These people had to cross more than 50 kilometres of open ocean to reach the islands, making it one of the longest known sea journeys by ancient Arctic peoples.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that these early Arctic travelers had advanced skills and watercraft capable of carrying whole families safely across dangerous waters. It also reveals how they influenced the island’s environment by bringing nutrients from the sea, helping plants grow in a harsh landscape. This challenges previous ideas about how and when humans explored the Arctic.

**What's next step** – Scientists will likely continue studying the Kitsissut Islands and other nearby areas to learn more about early Arctic travel and how these people lived. Understanding their boats and routes better could change what we know about ancient human migration and survival in cold climates.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Over 4,000 years ago, Indigenous Paleo-Inuit people made long sea journeys to settle remote Arctic islands, showing early skill in maritime travel and shaping their environment.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les peuples autochtones ont navigué vers des îles arctiques éloignées il y a plus de 4 000 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 4 500 ans, la région arctique près du Groenland a changé. Une nouvelle zone d’eau libre, appelée polynie, s’est formée près des îles Kitsissut, situées au large de la côte nord-ouest du Groenland. Cela a rendu possible le voyage en mer dans un endroit généralement couvert de glace.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2019, des chercheurs dirigés par Matthew Walls ont étudié les îles Kitsissut et ont trouvé des preuves que les peuples autochtones paléo-inuits y vivaient il y a plus de 4 000 ans. Ils ont découvert les restes de tentes circulaires et un os d’oiseau datant d’environ 4 400 ans. Ces peuples ont dû traverser plus de 50 kilomètres d’océan ouvert pour atteindre les îles, ce qui est l’un des plus longs voyages en mer connus des anciens peuples arctiques.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que ces premiers voyageurs arctiques avaient des compétences avancées et des embarcations capables de transporter des familles entières en toute sécurité à travers des eaux dangereuses. Elle révèle aussi comment ils ont influencé l’environnement des îles en apportant des nutriments de la mer, aidant les plantes à pousser dans un paysage difficile. Cela remet en question les idées précédentes sur la façon et le moment où les humains ont exploré l’Arctique.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques continueront probablement à étudier les îles Kitsissut et les zones environnantes pour en apprendre davantage sur les premiers voyages arctiques et la vie de ces peuples. Mieux comprendre leurs bateaux et leurs routes pourrait changer nos connaissances sur la migration humaine ancienne et la survie dans les climats froids.

**Une phrase clé** – Il y a plus de 4 000 ans, les peuples paléo-inuits autochtones ont réalisé de longs voyages en mer pour s’installer sur des îles arctiques éloignées, montrant leurs compétences maritimes précoces et leur influence sur l’environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: Los pueblos indígenas navegaron a islas remotas del Ártico hace más de 4,000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 4,500 años, la región ártica cerca de Groenlandia cambió. Se formó una nueva zona de agua abierta, llamada polinia, cerca de las Islas Kitsissut, ubicadas frente a la costa noroeste de Groenlandia. Esto permitió viajar por mar en un lugar que normalmente está cubierto de hielo.

**Qué pasó** – En 2019, investigadores liderados por Matthew Walls estudiaron las Islas Kitsissut y encontraron evidencia de que los pueblos indígenas Paleo-Inuit vivían allí hace más de 4,000 años. Descubrieron restos de tiendas circulares y un hueso de ave que data de hace unos 4,400 años. Estas personas tuvieron que cruzar más de 50 kilómetros de océano abierto para llegar a las islas, uno de los viajes marítimos más largos conocidos de los antiguos pueblos árticos.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo muestra que estos primeros viajeros árticos tenían habilidades avanzadas y embarcaciones capaces de transportar familias enteras de manera segura a través de aguas peligrosas. También revela cómo influyeron en el medio ambiente de la isla al traer nutrientes del mar, ayudando a que las plantas crecieran en un paisaje difícil. Esto desafía las ideas anteriores sobre cómo y cuándo los humanos exploraron el Ártico.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos probablemente continuarán estudiando las Islas Kitsissut y áreas cercanas para aprender más sobre los primeros viajes árticos y cómo vivían estas personas. Comprender mejor sus barcos y rutas podría cambiar lo que sabemos sobre la migración humana antigua y la supervivencia en climas fríos.

**Una frase clave** – Hace más de 4,000 años, los pueblos indígenas Paleo-Inuit realizaron largos viajes por mar para asentarse en islas remotas del Ártico, mostrando habilidades tempranas en navegación y su influencia en el ambiente.
